reporting-org.narrative: UTZ - joined forces with Rainforest Alliance

title.narrative: Building capacities for sector change: country program Indonesia

description.narrative: In 2020 we will have strengthened the lobby and advocacy capacity of civil society organizations in Indonesia on productivity, farmer group strengthening, gender and climate & water. As a result we will see an improvement of policy environment (both government and companies) and support services in these countries related to these themes. These themes are: 1. Sustainable productivity Raising smallholder productivity in a sustainable way is a key component of sector transformation. It is needed to increase income of the farmer and increase production while lowering the environmental footprint. 2. Smallholder inclusion & farmer group strengthening The aim is to increase the inclusion of smallholders in supply-chain driven sustainability programs. Strengthening farmer organizations is seen as an important way to increase the bargaining power of smallholder farmers in the supply chain. 3. Women’s empowerment and gender The goal is to increase the inclusion of women in certification and access to benefits as well as to reduce discrimination and violence against women. 4. Climate and water The focus is on up scaling of best practices in smallholder adaptation to climate change and sustainable water use.
SP-INO Building capacities for sector change: country program Indonesia

title.narrative: Country Scan

description.narrative: During the first part of the inception phase of the program (December 2015-March 2016) UTZ Country Representatives / SP focal points, supported by external consultants and UTZ Amsterdam staff, carried out a deeper analysis of the sector(s) and themes proposed for their countries to develop a more focused approach for the SP program. The objective of the Country Scans was “to provide a situational analysis on each sector and theme per country assessing the current state with regards to the relevant thematic SP objectives, clearly formulating the causes of the problem that need addressing and identify opportunities for interventions and provide recommendations on potential partners for these interventions.” The Country Scan documents are based on our own experience in the countries, but also document review, conversations/interviews with experts, key informants including Dutch embassy staff, national and international organizations, and workshop results with many of these actors.

title.narrative: # of country scans

comment.narrative: 2 country scans are completed (1 for Indonesia and 1 for India)
10-01-2018: 2 country scans completed (1 for Indonesia and 1 for India)

title.narrative: Country Plan

description.narrative: During the second part of the inception phase of the program (April-July 2016) UTZ Country Representatives / SP focal points, supported by external consultants and UTZ Amsterdam staff in drafting the country plans. The purpose of the SP country program plan is to set out a strategic direction for sector change in the country and serves as a framework. This plan clearly states UTZ goals for the country the Theory of Change to guide interventions as well as the budget for said activities. Overall, the SP Country Plan will serve as a guide for the next years, as well as a basis for the year plans that will be formulated for 2017 to 2020.

title.narrative: # of country plans

comment.narrative: 1 country plan is completed for Indonesia
10-01-2018: 1 country plan completed for Indonesia

title.narrative: Ultimate Outcome 1: Improved inclusion of the voice of female and male smallholders and workers

description.narrative: Improved inclusion of the voice of female and male smallholders and workers in policy/law-making processes

title.narrative: DD3 # of more inclusive policy/law-making processes

description.narrative: Voices, needs and interests of male and female farmers, smallholders and workers are better included in the development of policies and services

comment.narrative: 29-04-2019: 1. Kalimajari speaking actively and suggesting ideas at CSP (Cocoa platform) & government Government has also become more open to suggestions and easier to approach, government is more communicative with other stakelholders and involved real players in the field for program development; Kalimajari collecting input from young farmers to have their voices heard 2. KSS Cooperative has become more aware of its own gender inequality. Before women cannot become members, now they can. Women are highly considered for managerial positions, women get more priority for trainings, women are not shamed into public speaking 3. BITRA/SCOPI: Through SP, BITRA is also now linked with the national platform of coffee where it participated in advocating to national government through SCOPI-hosted meetings, and some of BITRA staffs have also facilitated gender workshop to government extension workers through SCOPI meetings

29-04-2020: 1) CSP has facilitated public dialog toward new government cocoa program 2) farmers in 3 villages are repeating the GALS (Gender Action Learning) trainings; female farmers begin to speak up 3)BITRA: Village administration involves group representatives in village discussions/deliberations". Female and youth coffee farmers are involved in discussions, training, garden activities and decision making

29-04-2021: 1. The central and regional governments actively encouraged the government through an MOU to allocate budget in the RPJMD and RPJMDes, for farmers training, and seed logistics program development scheme. 2. Farmers express their opinions in ESCP. 3. Women and youth farmers trained by BITRA are more involved in trainings, activities and decision making on the farm (planting, fertilizing, harvesting, etc). They are also involved in the musrenbangdes. 4. 5 new cocoa purchasers decided to purchase fermented Cocoa (Valrhona, Cocoa Beans Trading, Ubud Raw, Delco, and Krakakoa); (although 3 of them cancelled earlier purchases due to the pandemic). 5. More youth are involved in (sustainable) cocoa production in Jembrana. 6. In 2020 Gapoktan Mitra Jaya Rindingan Abadi, Pekon Penantian, Ulu Belu District, Tanggamus Regency became more organized and had succeeded in growing their capital from the original 3 million to 50 million; They have also compiled a draft statutes and bylaws which includes mainstreaming gender in the form of changes in women's participation at the domestic and group levels, division of roles in the domestic sphere. The cooperative had also been involved in joint nursery training with BPDAS. 7. In 2020, the Head of Ulu Belu Sub-District, Tanggamus District, expressed interest to replicate the formation of KUPS and its training using village funds in 6 other Pekons in Ulubelu District.

title.narrative: Ultimate Outcome 2: Policy changes & implementation

description.narrative: Policies are better in line with the needs of female and male farmers, smallholders and workers; Adequate implementation of policies;

title.narrative: DD1 # of ((inter)national) standards and policies implemented

description.narrative: Adequate implementation of policies

comment.narrative: 29-04-2019: 1. Cocoa: Food Crop Department has allocated 80 million budget for sustainable cocoa development (Kalimajari/CSP) 2. Coffee The government buyed PBKO traps (pilot technology for trapping pests instead of spraying with chemicals) and distributed to farmers (TOBA project) 3. During a meeting between Kalimajari and the Directorate General of Estate Crop at the Agri Ministry, the government declared commitment to enforce law no 67 and has supported Kalimajari to build fermentation model by delivering about 10,000 USD cocoa processing machine and equipments to our project site 4. Climate responsive farming has been diseminated through Master Trainer Camp involving government officials and extension workers from 15 provinces, our TOBA partners BITRA and CCROM-Climate Center led two sessions on coffee phenology and climate adaptation, and gender mainstreaming
Target value for this period has not been defined yet.

29-04-2020: 1) More than 1 billion rupiah has been allocated by government toward sustainable coffee farming 2) All Jembrana District OPD and DPR (legislative- all levels) provide regulatory support to the cocoa sustainability regulations and allocate funds

title.narrative: DD2 # of policy changes that UTZ /partners contributed to

description.narrative: Policies are better in line with the needs of (female) smallholders, (female) farmers and (female) farm workers, based on their needs and interests

comment.narrative: 29-04-2019: 1. Kalimajari: involvement of NP / CSO / Local government to develop cocoa clusters (fermentation) 2. BITRA: The government allocates a budget for empowering coffee farmers in 2018. This means the government has changed their programming priority to our project. This relates to how the national budget being transferred to regional budget, allocated into our project sites 3. A company POD has committed funding for women and cocoa project as an upscaling of SUBAK
29-04-2020: 1)National government has supported the SUBAK modeling and made it a reference in policy public hearing

title.narrative: Ultimate Outcome 3: Improvement of services

description.narrative: Services are better in line with the needs of female and male farmers, smallholders and workers; increased funding for services

title.narrative: DD1 # of new or improved government/company programs & services with budget allocation that are targeted and tailored to the needs of female and male smallholders and workers (related to the theme)

description.narrative: Services are better in line with the needs of (female) smallholders, (female) farmers and (female) farm workers, based on their needs and interests; increased funding for services

comment.narrative: Target value for this period has not been defined yet.

18-07-2019: 1. Credit services are better targeted, financial institutions are able to provide services to women farmers and understand how climate threats can factor into the credit scheme's timeline. More institutions engaged 2. Through advocacy in gender issues, the Office of Women Empowerment and Child Protection has started designing a program for specific women in cocoa 3. BITRA and ECOM have established farmer field schools in three districts-closer to farms, district governments were involved and made plans to co-finance activities from 2019 regional budgetting

29-04-2020: 1) BAPPEDA Jembrana Regency, allocated funds from the P3AP2KB Office for the PPKS gender program which will increase stakeholders' commitment regarding the Sustainable Cocoa program to be more gender transformative 2) A number of districts in Sulawesi are implementing SUBAK fermentation model and exploring niche market 3) 26 registered buyers support sustainable cocoa program, commit to price support and value added appreciation in the sustainable cocoa value chain and contribute to increase productivity 4) The village government allocates village funds for the BITRA program and procurement of coffee equipment (Samosir, Simalungun, Karo). The village government (village head) is involved in the activities carried out by the group and BITRA. 5)The central government (Ministry of Agriculture) synergizes the training program with SCOPI. There are 3 SCOPI-regional Government MoUs. Regional and local governments to contribute and commit to budgeting farmers' training in the RPJMD and RPJMDES".

29-04-2021: 1. In 2020 more farmers (56.149 in 13 Prov) received intensive GAP training up to 4 times a year, delivered in their local language at the location and time agreed with the farmers. 2. In 2020, 70 Master trainers are still active (from 190 trained) and they have received standard training materials GAP and Pest Harvest (part of NSC) as well as other knowledge related to climate change and other materials 3. In 2019 - 2020, 15 extension workers and 5 NGO members in KPH Kotaagung Utara, Batutegi, and Pesisir Barat, Tanggamus and Pesisir Barat districts have improved capacity in agroforestry. 4. In 2019, the Lampung Province Bappeda increased the budget for the Batutegi Forest Management Unit to IDR 175 million.

title.narrative: Baseline Report

description.narrative: The baseline provides an elaborate context-analysis per country, containing details about capacity of partners and the current state regarding the thematic goals for L&A. The baseline focuses on three main areas: a. Description of baseline situation of context and stakeholders b. Baseline of outcomes of ToC c. Capacities assessment

title.narrative: # of baseline reports

comment.narrative: 1 baseline report is completed for Indonesia
10-01-2018: 1 baseline report completed for Indonesia

title.narrative: Pathway 1: UTZ engages in direct Lobby & Advocacy

description.narrative: UTZ engages in direct L&A, knowledge sharing, awareness raising and linking actors

title.narrative: DD3 # of issues brought forward by UTZ, partners and MSPs included in the agenda of public and private policy makers

description.narrative: Agenda setting

comment.narrative: tbu

04-06-2019: Kalimajari convinced govt on reviewing cocoa policy (quality premiums) 2. Gender advocacy has been conducted at regional level in Jembrana, and the Office of Women Empowerment and Child Protection is now designing a specific intervention related to women and cocoa 3. We have brought up the issue of added value tax, now being discussed among stakeholders at the national platform 4. Post-harvest management has been included in the Indonesian Cocoa Roadmap;
29-04-2020: Sustainability issue discussed with private sectors at Jakarta Coffee Week through National Platform of Coffee (SCOPI)

title.narrative: DD3 # of advocacy messages and evidence used in political statements, policies, plans/media items by stakeholders

description.narrative: Discursive change

comment.narrative: tbu
29-04-2019: Buyers Cocoa companies expresed they see the potential of sourcing fermented premium beans
29-04-2020: 1) Partnership with CSP has successfully advocated for government intervention in agri-input nationwide

29-04-2021: 1. In 2020 AJI (Alliance of Independent Journalists) Bandar Lampung, socialized RUKO activities and published lobby and advocacy lessons learned in a book on social forestry. 2. In 2020, PERSAKI (Indonesian Forestry Scholar Association, Bandar Lampung branch) issued recommendations related to forest management in Lampung. 3. In 2020, LBH (Bandar Lampung) was involved in the preparation of an Academic Paper for forest management in Lampung, as a follow-up to the recommendations of the Ruko Persaki dan Ruko AJI series of webinars. 4. On November 2, 2020, the Governor of Lampung approved the approach used by Ruko in social forestry, provided that right to clear land would be given only to local people who had been living in the area and not to new people. The governor also agreed to encourage the academic paper prepared by RuKo to be considered in a Pergub related to forest management in Lampung.

29-04-2020: 1)Partnership with WWF-RuKo in Lampung addresses the issue of deforestation by coffee farmers and measure the improvement of forest function and protection of biodiversity. 2)Partnership with CSP and Swisscontact addresses inequality in the value chain of cocoa which affects productivity 3) A partnership between RUKO and CCROM has been established to hire CCROM's service to establish baseline (Oct 2019) 4)MARS has joined our gender initiative. 5)LDC has committed to become the offtaker of our coffee-forest partnership in BBS

DD3 # of MSP's, coalitions, networks & umbrella organizations formed or strengthened

description.narrative: MSPs, coalitions, networks & umbrella organizations formed / with increased capacities & space for participation

comment.narrative: tbu
29-04-2019: BITRA participating in SCOPI; Kalimajari participating in CSP

29-04-2021: RUKO 1. In 2019-2020, BPDAS held a program coordination with Ruko where Ruko was asked to provide assistance to forest farmer groups in the RHL BPDAS area, Bandar Lampung. 2. From 2019 - 2020, the government, including Bappeda and Assistant II, began to change their perspective and started to accept Ruko and to appreciate the program; This had also resulted in the speed process (only taking 2 days) of the preparation of the SK for the Monitoring and Recovery of the Catchment Team for the Batu Tegi Area, and assistant II support to report the activities to the Governor. 3. In 2020, Ruko became a member of SCOPI so that it can further voice the issue of coffee agroforestry at the national level.
30-04-2020: 1 new: RUKO (CSO consortium) & 2 ongoing: SCOPI & CSP

title.narrative: Pathway 6: Improve UTZ tools & training, improve code implementation
# of PO's that make use of the tools to provide better services or better implement the code

description.narrative: PO improve services to their farmers; improved code implementation

comment.narrative: tbu
29-04-2019: 10 coffee farmer groups at three districts (Karo, Simalungun and Samosir) in TOBA project

29-04-2021: 1. ESCP farmers have adopted GAP and optimized their land according to the maintenance schedule in their respective farms. 2. Farmers trained by BITRA in the 3 Project Areas experienced increase in their knowledge and skill in coffee farming, and had improved their coffee farming practices in terms of pruning, treatment, seeding, protective crops . 3. In 2020 KTH Margorukun VI pekon Ngarip, KPH Batutegi received a coffee dome solar dryer and trained coffee farmers ("champions") on how to improve the quality of their coffee (BBS area).

comment.narrative: tbu
29-04-2019: 10 coffee farmer groups at three districts (Karo, Simalungun and Samosir) in TOBA project
